3.00.text:
Artists' materials are very dangerous and can cause
injury or death! Use in a well-ventilated area,

7.00.text:
read all warning labels, and keep out of
reach of children! Use at your own risk!

11.33.text:
I want to teach you how to mix colors and
how to match colors from life with oil paint.

16.82.text: I have a silver cup sitting on this table here.

20.09.text:
The first thing to do is to figure out the various
color groups that exist in this still life.

25.98.text:
If you want to know more about color groups,
you can go watch a tutorial

29.69.text:
that's specifically about choosing color
groups, because it's important.

33.26.text: In this still life, we have three color groups.

36.00.text:
We have the silver cup, the background,
and the tabletop.

41.95.text:
I'm going to start by mixing the
colors in the silver cup.

46.28.text:
We're going to start with the very darkest color,
which is going to be black,

50.20.text: but I can check and make sure.

52.57.text:
I have some black already painted
on my color checker,

56.58.text:
and I'm going to compare it to
the area right under the lip here...

62.50.text: on the silver cup is definitely black.

66.37.text: In fact, it's blacker than black.

68.15.text:
That's one of the first things that
I should explain to you.

71.90.text:
There's a difference between the
range of color that we have.

76.42.text:
The darkest we can possibly
go is black paint.

79.57.text: In real life, you can go even darker.

81.86.text:
You can look into a shadow which is
actually even darker than black paint.

86.22.text: So, if I hold out my color checker and compare it

89.06.text: to the area right under the lip of the cup,

93.07.text:
and it's hard to see this in a picture,
but in real life,

96.02.text:
that shadow area on the silver cup is
actually darker than black paint.

100.60.text: Therefore, I'm going to paint it black.

103.97.text: Let me start by mixing some black paint.

106.46.text: I've got to really make sure my brush is clean,

109.10.text:
so I always pick up a little black paint
and work it into my bristles

112.82.text:
and make sure there's no milky, white paint
that's going to come out and pollute my black.

120.12.text:
So clean it real good.  Make sure your brush
is black, black, black.

125.28.text: Then, I'm going to take some black paint,

138.37.text:
If you want a warm black, you can add more brown.
If you want a cold black, you can add more blue.

146.42.text: I'm just going to start by mixing up some black paint,

152.84.text:
because I know I need it for this cup,
and I'm going to transfer some of it,

157.71.text:
and that will be my first step
in the silver cup.

162.80.text: Now I'm going to paint a little line of that

167.05.text:
and I'm going to use that to make sure
that my next step

170.47.text:
is a good step.  You'll see what
I mean in a second.

173.49.text:
So here's my black.  Maybe I'll get a
little more of that out.

178.19.text:
I'm going to run out of blue and brown
real quick here.

182.38.text:
OK, so now I've mixed my first step,
which was black,

186.58.text:
and the next thing I need to do is mix
one step lighter than that.

192.38.text: The first question I'm faced with is:

194.95.text: "How do I lighten up this black?"

196.75.text: I can lighten it only one of two ways.

199.34.text:
I can either add white or yellow, that's it.
I don't have any other choice.

205.80.text:
If I need to lighten this color,
if I add yellow,

208.74.text:
it's going to bump it over here to the
green, and orange, and yellow side.

215.25.text: If I add, on the other hand, white,

219.93.text:
it's going to push it over here to
the purple side.

223.03.text: To the blue side / purple side.

225.56.text:
Keep this color wheel, and
make a duplicate of this for yourself

230.34.text:
to keep as you're mixing colors,
to look at.

234.27.text:
If I want to lighten it up, if I add white,
it's going to make it purple, or blue,

240.92.text:
and if I add yellow, it's going to make it green
or down here toward the orange/yellow side.

245.67.text:
And so my question is, if I was
painting a lemon...

249.39.text:
yellow lemon, then it would be obvious.
I would add yellow to lighten it up one step.

255.06.text: If I was painting a purple book,

259.90.text:
then I would add, most definitely, white.
That's an obvious one.

264.41.text: But this is neither of those, so what would I do?

268.56.text: I would add a little bit of both,

271.13.text:
because I want to keep it right
down in the middle

273.28.text:
If I add a little bit of white and a little bit
of yellow, I'm going to be right here in the middle

277.45.text:
which is where I want to be, because
this cup is a neutral.

281.87.text:
Now, if you're confused, and you're
not sure what you should add,

285.38.text:
add a little bit of something to lighten
it up, doesn't matter.

289.23.text:
And then when we get our color checker
out and compare it,

292.84.text: then we can make a further adjustment.

296.04.text:
You shouldn't be afraid.
Just go for it.

298.49.text:
Once you have something to look at, then
it's going to be real easy to make the adjustment.

302.29.text: You'll see what I mean in a second.

304.19.text:
Let's lighten this up by adding
a little bit of yellow

307.94.text: and a little bit of white

315.87.text:
to keep it sort of neutral.
Right down the middle.

320.52.text: The first step, or first question I have to ask,

323.38.text: before I even think about the color,

325.76.text: always make sure your step is in line.

330.76.text:
There's no point in refining your color
and getting it perfect

336.21.text:
Like this is most definitely wrong, because
that is not nearly enough of a step.

350.28.text:
Add some more yellow,
and some more white,

354.62.text: and mix that in and see what we've got.

358.80.text: Not worrying about my color at this point.

362.00.text:
I"m really just trying to get
my step to be right.

367.30.text:
There's nothing wrong if I need
to add white or yellow.

370.93.text: When I feel like my color is getting too green,

373.90.text:
by all means, add some white
instead of more yellow.

381.85.text: but the first priority is to get our step right,

385.33.text:
and then we'll fine-tune the color,
and get it perfect.

392.90.text: So, let's see how this step looks.

396.68.text:
Not big enough.
Needs to be a little bigger than that.

400.48.text:
Just a little bit.  So I'm just going
to take a little bit more yellow,

407.69.text: and you can go watch another tutorial

410.46.text:
to find out exactly what I think
about all these colors

414.50.text: under the tutorial about my palette.

418.33.text:
This is burnt umber, French ultramarine,
permanent alizarin crimson,

422.90.text:
cadmium yellow pale, and
titanium white.

428.22.text:
But I just call them white, yellow,
red, blue, and brown.

434.90.text:
It's best for you to think
about color in those terms also.

439.88.text:
You only need to think of your
color in terms of:

442.89.text:
"Does it need to be more blue?"
"Does it need to be more purple?"

446.96.text:
"Does it need to be more red?"
"Does it need to be more orange?"

449.95.text:
"Does it need to be more yellow?" or
"Does it need to be more green?"

456.10.text: Let's see.  Is that a good step?

458.63.text:
Still a little bit small, so I'm going to
bump it up one more time

463.46.text:
and it's kind of looking...
well let's just leave it.

467.41.text:
It might be too blue, which means
I need to add more Burnt Umber,

472.16.text: or I could add yellow and red...

474.65.text: orange, but burnt umber is like a dark orange.

478.03.text: Let's see.  This is probably a good step now.

482.37.text: So the step is good, that's question number one.

486.40.text:
Now we're going to look for:
"Where does this step exist in the teacup?"

495.42.text:
Let me explain that again,
and this is really important.

501.92.text:
One of the biggest mistakes that people make
when they start to mix colors

507.21.text:
is you pick up the color,
and you paint it on your color checker,

510.64.text:
and then you hold it up,
and you start noticing things.

513.65.text:
You start saying, "Oh, wow.  This color exists
over here, on the background!"

518.96.text: Or, "Look! This color exists over there!"

523.63.text:
Maybe you made your step too big,
or maybe you got something out of whack.

527.41.text:
Then you start to see things,
and you start noticing

530.37.text: "Oh, look, this is down there in the table."

533.00.text: and you start saving these little bits of color

535.62.text:
and you end up with this palette with little
bits of color all over the place,

539.42.text:
instead of an organized palette,
like I'm about to put out.

543.92.text: OK.  So, my step is good,

547.39.text:
now I'm going to paint it
on my color checker.

553.32.text:
Once I've determined that my step is good,
and I've decided it's a good step, period,

558.43.text: I"m not going to worry about that anymore.

560.43.text: The next thing, is not to hold this out

565.09.text: and check the color where it doesn't belong.

569.56.text:
You've got to move the color checker
into the exact spot

573.55.text: where you find that the value —

576.09.text:
the brightness and the darkness —
the value of the color is the same.

580.50.text:
There's no point judging this color
unless I'm holding it in the right spot.

585.56.text: It's real easy to miss that.

589.30.text: And so, I'm going to move it around.

601.57.text:
the bottom, and I'll just check
all over the place.

605.85.text:
Once I identify that point in the cup
where the paint

610.11.text: is the exact same value — same brightness —

613.70.text:
as the teacup, and I'm going to
move it around to find that spot...

617.95.text: Right here, the paint is too bright.

620.63.text: Right here, the paint is too dark.

623.02.text:
So, somewhere between those 
two there has to be a point,

627.44.text:
and it might even be hard to see,
because it's just in transition,

631.19.text:
but move it around, and see where the
easiest place to see that color is.

635.68.text: I think right there is the easiest spot.

641.89.text:
Once I've got it in the right spot, then I'm
going to make a judgement about the color.

647.24.text:
Let me repeat all of that,
because that's important.

650.43.text: First, I get my step right.

653.32.text:
I make sure the step's right,
I don't worry too much about the color.

656.64.text:
I don't worry about the saturation, whether it's
too yellow, or too red, or too purple.

661.00.text: Just worry about: "Is it a good step?"

663.53.text: Once I've decided it's a good step,

666.00.text:
I move the color checker into the position
where the step matches,

670.05.text:
where the value matches.  Maybe the color 
doesn't match, but the value matches.

674.25.text: Then I make a judgement about the color.

677.82.text: I decide "which way to I need to bump this?"

680.85.text: Does it need to be more blue?

682.99.text: Does it need to be more purple?

685.55.text:
Does it need to be more red?
Does it need to be more orange?

688.54.text:
Does it need to be more yellow?
Or does it need to be more green?

693.98.text: That's what you do every time.

696.02.text:
Usually what happens is you hold up, and you say,
"Oh, yeah.  Mine looks too green."

701.17.text:
Well, you're done.
You've discovered what the difference is.

705.84.text:
But sometimes you'll hold it up,
and you'll think,

709.32.text: "I don't know.  I can't tell." and you're baffled.

712.39.text:
So, if you're baffled, that's when you
need to go through those six questions.

716.91.text:
The three primary colors,
and the three secondary colors.

720.23.text:
If you can't answer one question,
you'll be able to answer the next.

724.24.text: If I look at it, and I say to myself,

726.77.text:
"Which one is more yellow?
I don't know which one is more yellow."

732.55.text:
And then I say, "Oh, yeah.  I can see.
Mine is definitely more blue."

738.34.text:
"Which one is more green?"
"Oh, yeah.  The paint is definitely more blue-green."

743.08.text:
And that's exactly what it is.
It's more blue, and it's more green.

747.55.text: Now I'm going to go over to the color wheel,

750.16.text:
and I've decided that my paint is too blue-green.
Right here.

756.10.text:
It's both too blue, and it looks a little too green.
It's looks too blue-green.

760.53.text: So, we go to the opposite side of the color wheel

763.41.text: which is right over here, between orange and red,

767.06.text:
and so we get a reddish-orange,
or an orangey-red.

771.61.text:
We're going to add mostly red to it,
but a little bit of yellow

780.12.text:
So, we'll do exactly that.
We'll get a lot of red

787.84.text:
and, this yellow is really powerful,
so just a tiny touch of it.

794.99.text:
There.  I've added some reddish-orange,
which will kill the blue-green,

801.40.text:
because you always kill a color
with the color on the opposite side.

805.59.text: So if your color is too red, you add green.

808.56.text:
Too yellow, you add purple.
Too blue, you add orange.

817.68.text: And, I probably didn't add enough.

822.05.text:
But when I do add a color to it,
I always want to check my step again,

826.96.text:
because if you add enough color,
you'll throw your step out of line.

831.63.text:
Especially if I was adding just red, that Permanent
Alizarin Crimson would bring the color down.

842.15.text:
This is definitely closer, but I think
it needs just a little—

846.37.text: It's still too blue-green.  Just slightly.

848.85.text: So, we'll add a little bit more yellow

853.53.text: and a little bit more red.

867.29.text:
Again, I'm moving it to that point
where the value is identical,

871.36.text: and then I judge the color,

874.02.text: I think it still, just the slightest bit, needs to be—

877.41.text: That is a little bit more orange than my color is.

890.68.text:
I'm thinking my step might be getting
a little dark, but we'll check.

903.21.text: Let's look at this color again.

909.45.text: This is just one step from black

913.00.text: and I think that's a good color right there.

916.50.text: OK, maybe the teeniest bit more orange.

921.48.text:
Another thing that happens when people
mix colors is if the color is really close,

929.41.text:
they'll look at it, and they'll think they
can see a difference, and they'll say,

934.16.text:
"I can see there is a difference, but
I can't tell what it is."

938.31.text:
When it's that close, and it's that hard to see,
then you've got it.

943.46.text: Your eye is so sensitive to difference,

947.05.text:
sometimes you think you see a difference,
but it's so close, you can't even tell.

952.02.text:
If it's that close, and you can't tell,
then you're close enough.

956.73.text: You really don't have to be that perfect with it.

960.46.text: This should be our next step.

965.03.text: Definitely more "orangey" than it was originally.

968.18.text: Yeah, I like that.  That's perfect.

971.93.text:
So, there's our second step.
Our first step was black.

976.28.text: I'll transfer some of this over

979.96.text: and go on to the next step.

983.68.text:
I'm going to get out a little more blue
and brown, because I'm going to need it.

991.39.text:
I've got some more color out.
This blue is a little runny.

996.31.text: It will thicken up in a couple of days.

999.55.text:
We're going to go on one step, and
we need to make sure to draw a line here

1007.08.text:
so that I can check my next step
and make sure it's good.

1017.65.text:
I'm just creating some more base here
to start with.

1022.74.text: You can use burnt umber as your red, like I just did.

1026.36.text: If I add more brown to my black,

1030.74.text:
then I don't need to use the more
expensive permanent alizarin.

1035.32.text: But also, I like the way the brown mixes

1043.63.text: I like the way it works.

1046.08.text: I like to work with it.

1049.80.text: Let's see how this step is.

1053.46.text: I think that's a little bit big.

1056.91.text:
So, we're going to darken this
down a little more.

1065.57.text:
Then we'll compare the step, 
and I think that's pretty good step.

1070.93.text:
Now that the step is right, 
and again, let me repeat that.

1076.77.text: The first priority is getting the step right,

1079.39.text: and once we've determined that the step is right,

1081.72.text: then I go and check the color.

1084.58.text:
When I move the color checker to that
position where the value is identical,

1093.30.text:
it looks to me like my color
is the slightest bit too "orangey".

1098.08.text: It needs to be a little more blue.

1101.10.text: So I add a little bit of blue to that.

1104.19.text:
The blue is going to darken it down,
so I'm going to add a little bit of white,

1107.51.text: which will bring out the blue.

1114.51.text: I make sure my step is still good.

1118.99.text:
Which it is, that's a good step.
If anything, it's maybe a little bit too big.

1128.90.text: Now, when I hold it exactly at that point,

1133.02.text:
before I judge the color I'm going to
identify where the value is the same.

1137.46.text:
Once I identify that, then I'm going
to ask myself if the color is different.

1141.72.text: To me, it looks just perfect.

1146.25.text: I'm going to paint a line of that, so that

1151.09.text: I have something to compare my step to.

1161.63.text: We're going to lighten that pile up one more step.

1179.08.text:
We'll see if that's big enough.
I don't think it is.

1190.53.text:
More yellow.
Maybe more white than yellow.

1199.53.text:
That's a pretty good step.
It's maybe a little bit too small.

1212.60.text:
What we're doing is we're creating a base.
These are not the final colors that we'll use.

1218.35.text:
This is just a palette that
we're going to use

1221.18.text: to then mix even more colors when we paint.

1224.23.text:
But it's going to be real easy
if we start with this base.

1228.67.text:
Then, to adjust a color, when you start
to paint, if you notice there's more red,

1235.20.text:
like a red glow down in the bottom,
you can easily take what you've got,

1238.83.text:
and just shift it around a little bit
with other colors.

1244.41.text:
Let's see how this step is.
I think that's a good step.

1250.78.text: Our step is good, and we'll move it

1253.75.text:
into the position where the value is the same,

1259.18.text: And I think our color is good.

That's a good color.
Paint a line in for our next step.

1274.29.text: And we'll just lighten that up one more step.

1291.00.text:
We could go a little bit lighter than that.
It could be a little bit bigger.

1303.08.text: OK, so that's a good step.

1308.34.text: Now I'm going to move it into position.

1310.58.text:
If I go up inside the ellipse there,

I need a little more base color here,

1365.13.text:
That's a good step.

I'm looking for the position

I think that mine is just the

1394.03.text:
I'm going to add a little bit of red,
because on the color wheel,

1403.82.text: Make sure my step is still good.

1416.80.text: That still looks a little bit too green.

1423.23.text:
I'm going to add a little bit of white
to counteract the red,

1426.47.text: because the red will darken it.

1442.53.text: Paint a line of that for our next step.

1456.69.text:
We're going to just keep on going.
We're going to lighten it up one more step.

1465.07.text: And again I need to get some more base in here.

1486.62.text:
Let's see how our step is.
And I think it's not big enough.

1493.51.text: It needs to be bigger than that.

1504.76.text: I don't want my color to get too green.

1507.90.text: Well, maybe a little bit of yellow.

1513.51.text:
So that's a pretty good step.
Now I'll check this color on the silver cup.

1519.81.text:
And this color is very close
to getting up near the shine.

1526.58.text: What I'm going to do is hold it in position.

1529.62.text:
If I hold it on the shine,
I can see that my color is too dark.

1533.09.text:
But if I hold it just under that,
I can see that my color is too light.

1538.68.text: So I know that somewhere right in there

1541.76.text: the color exists, right beneath the shine.

1545.40.text:
So I hold it there, and
I try to make a judgement about the color,

1548.67.text: and in my case, I think it's exactly right.

1553.84.text:
That is probably the last color
we'll mix other than the shine.

1563.57.text:
The shine, the easiest way—
Let me just go ahead and mix it.

1568.67.text: Let's take some pure white paint

1573.29.text: and just look at it in terms of a step next to that.

1578.66.text: but we're going to tint it just a little bit.

1586.79.text: I could start with just pure white.

1589.74.text:
Put it on my color checker,
and all I'm going to ask myself...

1593.10.text:
Very typically, the shine on something
is going to be brighter

1596.68.text:
than you can possibly mix.
It's actually brighter than white paint.

1600.40.text: What I'll do is I'll hold white paint out

1604.41.text:
and if the shine is—
It looks like it's pretty close, actually.

1607.95.text: But I'm just looking for the difference in the color.

1610.69.text: And I notice the shine is a little bit more yellow-orange.

1616.24.text:
I'm going to take pure white paint —
and this is the way I always handle shines —

1620.46.text: pure white paint, with a clean brush,

1624.01.text:
and the only thing I'm going 
to tint it with is just a little—

1627.65.text:
And this is the shift.  If you notice that 
your shine was more blue-green,

1632.16.text:
then you would add blue and yellow
and nothing else.

1635.07.text:
But in this case, my shine
is a little bit more "orangey".

1640.42.text:
That's what I see when I hold it out
and compare it to white.

1643.15.text: It looks a little bit more orange-yellow.

1645.64.text:
I'm going to add just a touch
of yellow to pure white.

1655.87.text: Maybe a little bit of red because I said "orangey".

1659.21.text:
But in other words, no blue in there,
because that's just going to darken it down.

1662.87.text:
Which defeats the purpose, we want
to make the lightest color we can

1666.79.text:
that has just a little bit of a
yellow-orange shift to it.

1674.26.text:
It's just about a light as white paint is,
but it just has a tint to it.

1680.43.text:
Otherwise, you end up painting these
shines that are just white, white,

1684.21.text: and they just don't have the flavor of the light.

1688.35.text: And this yellow white has the flavor of the light.

1693.23.text:
Which now it does.  Now I feel like they
both have that sort of "orangey-ness" to them.

1698.17.text: That'll be our very lightest color,

1701.36.text:
which is really the shine.
And we'll put that over here.

1707.53.text:
OK, so that's that.
And then the other colors are the table,

1718.15.text: I could show it to you, but its the same deal.

1720.88.text: You start with the very darkest color,

1723.75.text: you work up in the same steps,

1727.87.text:
all the way until you get to the
lightest color in that section.

1731.41.text: Every time I check a color,

1733.63.text:
the very first thing you do
is make sure your step is good,

1736.86.text:
and once your step is good, you hold it out,
find that place where the value's the same.

1741.36.text:
Once you find that point,
then you judge the color,

1744.30.text: and the only questions you have to ask are

1748.69.text:
"Which one is more green?"
"Which one is more blue?"

1751.48.text:
"Which one is more purple?"
"Which one is more red?"

1755.28.text:
That's it.
Those are the only questions you have.

1757.46.text: Which one is lighter and which one is darker,

1760.04.text:
and then the color by asking
those six questions.

1764.82.text:
And that's it.
That's all there is to color mixing.

1767.58.text:
There's some basic rules that I've written out,
which you can look at.

1774.68.text:
These are basic rules that
you can keep in front of you.

1777.43.text:
Keep a color wheel in front of you,
and keep these basic rules in front of you.

1782.84.text: The only other thing I should talk about is

1786.50.text:
if you have something like...
let's say you have an orange.

1791.28.text:
Like this orange.
And one part of the orange is green,

1795.59.text:
and one part of the orange is very "orangey",
and they're all kind of mixed together.

1800.18.text:
You could treat that as two
different color groups.

1804.64.text:
Because it's all swirled together,
I just look at it like it's all part of the orange.

1808.75.text:
But what I'll do, is I'll mix a green version
and a red version.

1812.36.text:
Or an orange version.
So I have my orange colors,

1815.59.text: and then I have my green colors.

1817.89.text: I just mix them like two different color groups.

1823.01.text:
If you have something
like this white little vase sitting here,

1829.74.text:
and one side is all red because
there's some red flower on one side,

1834.78.text:
and the other side is all green, because there's
a big green leaf on the other side,

1841.04.text: and then you have the neutrals down the middle,

1844.66.text: you could just mix the neutral down the middle.

1848.32.text:
And then when you paint it, you could
just add red to get the red shades,

1854.50.text: or add green to get the green shades.

1857.16.text:
Just tint what you've got.  In other words,
just mix the neutrals down the middle

1860.86.text: and then just shift it green and shift it red.

1863.57.text: That's the easiest way to do it.

1865.64.text: If you wanted to really be super-accurate

1868.57.text:
then what you could do is just go ahead
and treat it like three different color groups.

1875.38.text:
One thing you shouldn't do,
is if you've got a color group,

1879.44.text: and you're mixing them, like this silver cup here,

1882.48.text:
and if there's a little red glow
over in the corner up in the top,

1887.37.text: and it's just one little part,

1889.08.text:
don't start chasing all these different
color shifts that you see.

1893.47.text: Sometimes you'll see all kinds of colors.

1895.70.text: If you're painting something that's reflective,

1898.36.text:
and it's reflecting all kinds of colors
from all over the place,

1901.27.text:
don't start chasing all those colors.
You can deal with those colors when you paint.

1905.88.text:
What you really want to do is just
mix your basic color steps

1909.71.text:
and have a real basic palette
that you can use to paint with.

1913.16.text:
And then when you start to paint,
you do more color mixing.

1916.39.text:
You can go watch the tutorial about
how to paint to see more about that.

1923.23.text:
My point is don't get bogged down chasing
all these little individual colors all over the place.

1930.25.text:
and just mix from the darkest to the lightest
in each one, and you're done.

1935.74.text: That's about it for mixing colors.
